Introduction

Factitious disorder imposed on self is characterized by the intentional falsification of symptoms or induction of illness with the goal of assuming the patient (ie, sick) role.  Patients often seek medical care repeatedly to meet their psychologic needs, and their deceptive behaviors are not associated with obvious external rewards (eg, money, housing).

Epidemiology and risk factors

The prevalence of factitious disorder is difficult to measure because the diagnosis is based on the intentional falsification of symptoms, although the prevalence is estimated to be approximately 0.1%-1% depending on the population (more frequently encountered in hospital settings).  Onset tends to occur in early adulthood and appears to be more common among women than men.

Several factors may contribute to the risk for factitious disorder, including psychologic factors (eg, concurrent personality disorder, history of adverse childhood events [eg, abuse, neglect]) and environmental factors (eg, childhood illness that resulted in significant medical attention).

Clinical presentation

Factitious disorder can present in many different ways, including:

  • Fabrication of symptoms
    • Simulation of symptoms on physical examination to suggest acute process (eg, simulating right lower quadrant pain to suggest appendicitis)
    • Falsification of medical history or forgery of medical records (eg, reporting history of cancer when never diagnosed, reporting grief symptoms due to death of spouse when never married)
  • Induction of illness or injury
    • Injection of foreign material (eg, feces) to induce skin infections
    • Surreptitious ingestion of medications (eg, warfarin, insulin, laxatives)
  • Manipulation of equipment or laboratory testing
    • Holding a thermometer next to a hot object
    • Pricking the finger and adding blood to a urine sample

Factors that can be associated with factitious disorder include:

  • Inconsistencies between reported symptoms and objective findings (eg, patient report of excessive vomiting despite no signs of dehydration and normal laboratory evaluation)
  • Atypical course of illness (eg, spontaneous recovery soon after admission, new or worsening symptoms preceding scheduled discharge)
  • Extensive work-up of symptoms with no clear diagnosis
  • Unusual acquiescence to invasive procedures or testing (eg, exploratory laparotomy)
  • Unexplained medical supplies in the patient's possession (eg, syringes in purse)
  • Extensive knowledge of medical conditions (eg, health care workers)
  • Refusal to sign a release of information for medical records

Diagnosis

For a diagnosis of factitious disorder, the following criteria must be met:

  • The patient intentionally engages in falsification of physical or psychologic signs or symptoms, or induction of injury or disease.
  • The patient presents to others as ill, impaired, or injured.
  • The deceptive behavior is evident even in the absence of obvious external rewards.
  • The behavior is not better explained by another mental disorder.

Differential diagnosis

The differential diagnosis of factitious disorder includes (

):

  • Malingering:  also includes deceptive behavior to simulate an illness; however, the intentional production of symptoms in malingering is motivated by external incentives (ie, secondary gain).  Malingering can coincide with factitious disorder because motivations can change depending on the situation.
  • Factitious disorder imposed on another:  involves intentional falsification or induction of illness in another person (eg, elderly parent, child); this diagnosis is given to the perpetrator and not the victim.  Factitious disorders imposed on self and on another are highly comorbid.
  • Somatic symptom disorder:  can also involve high health care use for somatic symptoms that are disruptive to daily life; however, symptoms are not intentionally feigned or induced.
  • Functional neurologic symptom disorder:  can involve motor or sensory neurologic symptoms; however, the symptoms are not intentionally produced and must be incompatible with recognized neurologic conditions.
  • Other medical conditions:  can coincide with factitious disorder, and deceptive behaviors may result in exacerbation of conditions (eg, nonadherence to antiepileptic medication, taking less insulin than recommended).

Management

Laboratory evaluation and/or imaging may be necessary for diagnostic work-up depending on a patient's clinical status and symptoms; specific testing may also be indicated if there is concern for factitious disorder (ie, when objective findings are inconsistent with patient report).  Examples include:

  • Evaluation of factitious hypoglycemia (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: Evaluation of hypoglycemia
    ):  Serum insulin and C-peptide levels can determine whether exogenous insulin or insulin secretagogues (eg, sulfonylureas) are being taken.
  • Evaluation of factitious hyperthyroidism (
    figure 1
    ):  Low serum thyroglobulin and low radioiodine uptake are suggestive of exogenous thyroid hormone ingestion.
  • Evaluation of factitious diarrhea (
    figure 2
    ):  Low stool osmolality may suggest the addition of water to stools, and hyperosmolality may suggest the addition of a concentrated fluid (eg, urine).  Stool electrolytes may show elevated magnesium or phosphate levels if saline osmotic laxatives are being taken; stool osmotic gap may be elevated with laxatives such as lactulose or polyethylene glycol.
  • Drug levels may indicate the use of recreational substances or surreptitious medication ingestions (eg, serum levels of calcium channel blockers, beta blockers for factitious hypotension, serum pseudoephedrine for factitious hypertension).

Management of factitious disorder is challenging because patients are likely to deny behaviors and seek care elsewhere once a diagnosis is discussed.  General recommendations for patients include the following:

  • Approach patients in an empathic and supportive manner to reduce the risk for escalation and aggression as well as leaving against medical advice.
  • Avoid unnecessary testing and specialist referrals (ie, pursue work-up based on objective clinical findings) and explain to patients why further testing is not indicated.
  • Share the current differential diagnosis, including factitious disorder, based on objective findings.
  • Emphasize that care is necessary and available for the patient.
  • Assess the risk for suicidality and comorbid psychiatric conditions; personality disorders (eg, borderline or histrionic), posttraumatic stress disorder, and substance use disorders are common.
  • Offer psychiatric consultation while emphasizing that the consult may help identify and cope with stressors.  If the patient declines, obtain psychiatric consultation to review the case and provide guidance on management.
  • Maintain safety by placing the patient on constant observation to prevent further self-injury.
  • Avoid attempts to obtain a confession because this is not necessary for further treatment and may escalate the situation.

Patients frequently decline treatment.  If the patient is agreeable, psychotherapy with cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) to address automatic negative thoughts about self and maladaptive coping mechanisms may be of benefit.

Prognosis

Factitious disorder is usually experienced as intermittent episodes and is associated with a poor prognosis.  Morbidity and mortality can result from the patient's deceptive behaviors to induce illness and/or iatrogenic causes.

Summary

Factitious disorder (

) imposed on self involves the intentional production of signs and symptoms to fulfill unmet psychologic needs (eg, receiving attention, feeling cared for).  Diagnostic testing is often indicated, although it should be based on objective findings.  Patients must be approached in an empathic and supportive manner to lessen the risk for escalation and/or the patient seeking care elsewhere.  Treatment with psychotherapy is often declined though may be of benefit for patients with factitious disorder.
